page.text: by Frédéric Lafitte, Dirk Van Heule and Julien Van hamme
A new package called boolfun is avail-
able for R users. The package provides tools to
handle Boolean functions, in particular for cryp-
tographic purposes. This document guides the
user through some (code) examples and gives a
feel of what can be done with the package.
A Boolean function is a mapping
Those mappings are of much interest in the design of
cryptographic algorithms such as secure pseudoran-
dom number generators (for the design of stream ci-
phers among other applications), hash functions and
block ciphers. The lack of open source software to
assess cryptographic properties of Boolean functions
and the increasing interest for statistical testing of
properties related to random Boolean functions (
) are the main motivations for the
The number of Boolean functions with n vari-
, i.e. 2 possible output values for each of
input assignments. In this search space of
, looking for a function which has specific
properties is impractical. Already for n
haustive search would require too many computa-
tional resources. Furthermore, most properties are
tographic community has been interested in evolu-
algorithms) to find an optimal function in this huge
space. Another way to tackle the computational diffi-
culties is to study algebraic constructions of Boolean
functions. An example of such constructions is to
start from two functions with m variables and to
combine them to get a function with n
that provably preserves or enhances some properties
of the initial functions. In both cases, the
package can be used to experiment on Boolean func-
tions and test cryptographic properties such as non-
linearity, algebraic immunity and resilience. This
short article gives an overview of the package. More
details can be found in the package vignettes.
In R, type install.packages("boolfun") in order to
install the package and library(boolfun) to load it.

to be defined over the input assignments. The posi-

Addition and multiplication are executed using
C code. The addition is straightforward given two
vectors of coefficients as it consists in making a
component-wise exclusive or of the input vectors.
The multiplication is built upon the addition of two
polynomials and the multiplication of two monomi-
als. Hence addition is computed in O
can be achieved using graph based representations
such as binary decision diagrams. For now, only vec-
are used which are sufficient to ma-
nipulate sets of Boolean functions having up to about
Depending on its cryptographic application, a
Boolean function needs to satisfy a set of properties
in order to be used safely. Some of those properties
cannot be satisfied simultaneously as there are trade-
offs between them. In this section we focus on two
properties, resilience and algebraic immunity, and
show how R can be used to illustrate the trade-off
The algebraic immunity of a Boolean function f is
defined to be the lowest degree of the nonzero func-
erty is used to assess the resistance to some algebraic
Resilience is a combination of two properties: bal-
ancedness and correlation immunity. A function is
balanced if its truth table contains as many zeros as
ones and correlation immune of order t if the proba-
bility distribution of its output does not change when
at most t input variables are fixed. Hence a function
is resilient of order t if its output remains balanced
even after fixing at most t input variables.
The following example illustrates the trade-off
# number of functions with n var
for( i in 1:N ) { # forall Boolean function
Figure 3: Resiliency of all functions with 3 variables.

The example code plots the resilience and the al-
gebraic immunity of all functions with 3 variables.

Observe that the search space of size 2
particular structure. The symmetry between the two
halves of the search space is justified in that a func-
tion with constant term zero, i.e. with f
0 will have the same properties as its complement
f (i.e. the same function with constant term 1).
Note also that in those figures the functions achiev-
ing the highest resiliencies belong to the second quar-
ter of the search space, which also seems more dense
in algebraically immune functions. Very similar plots
are observed when considering more variables.

A free open source package to manipulate Boolean
package also provides tools to handle Boolean
has been developed to evaluate some cryp-
tographic properties of Boolean functions and carry
statistical analysis on them. An effort has been made
to optimize execution speed rather than memory us-
age using C code. It is easy to extend this package
in order to add new functionality such as comput-
tation) symmetric Boolean functions, etc... as well as
